title: Dasaki compact servo 1:2 (2x) multiplier gearbox
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
1:2 multiplier for standard sized RC servo. My purpose was to get more speed from a cotinuous rotation servo, but it can be used also to get twice as much angle (for example to get 360 from a 180 degree servo for a pan-tilt unit).
In most standard servos there is no need to install the spacers, but some like the MG995 need them.
Use one M3x15mm cross flat head screw, two M3 washers and a M3 self locking nut.
See it in action here: https://youtu.be/DglwlFt9taQ Edit (2-apr-2016): As there is demand for a micro servo version, I've made and uploaded the corresponding models with the suffix "_micro" (note I haven't printed/tested these). If you are a curious maker / "tinker" / hacker, have a look at my blog:
www.therandomlab.com

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

comments.text:
Have you got the time and inclination to design a 4:1 in order to obtain a two-turn (720 degree) rotation?
Thanks
comments.author: dkender_1512

comments.text: At the moment I'm busy with other projects.
comments.author: dkender_1512

comments.text:
This is such a super idea.
Have you considered creating a parameterized version; i.e.,
Gear Ratios
16:8 = 2 to 1
18:6 = 3 to 1
20:5 = 4 to 1
It may not even be necessary to relocate the smaller gear axle hole.
Thank you for your design.
comments.author: dkender_1512

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback!
comments.author: dkender_1512

comments.text: This is well made! Well done! Almost exactly what I was looking for. Question: How hard would it be to reverse the gears? I'm looking for gear reduction for slower pan/tilt. I'm using 2x MG 995 Servos for my setup but when the camera is zoomed all the way in I do not have fine enough control. Would it be hard to get 2:1 out of this? Thanks.
comments.author: BrandonKuenzi

comments.text:
Thanks!
It could be done, however the drawback is that the 2:1 reduction would half the angle travel from 180deg to just 90deg. If you use a continuous rotation servo this wouldn't be problem, but you would loose the absolute position capability (you wouldn't know which is the current angle), unless you also add a feedback sensor/position encoder.
There are some commercial solutions, search for "5:1 Continuous Rotation Servo Power Gearbox".
Once I got some spare time I'll do a printable version.
comments.author: BrandonKuenzi

comments.text: Thanks for the quick reply. 90deg would be just fine for my use. Ill check out 5:1 but if you post a 2:1 I would print it in a heartbeat. I checked out your other stuff too. Impressive work.

comments.author: JuanS36

comments.text:
I modified it for a 9g sized 180 degree turnigy servo.
For the center harness and large gear I shrunk the X and Y axis to 0.58, leave the Z axis at 100%. A little sanding on the center harness is required to make it a nice fit. Drill out the screwhole for the small gear and use a threaded bolt to attach it. cut a cross servo horn to size so it fits in the large gear. put it together and you have a 9g 360 degree pan servo. (for a 90 degree servo you will offcourse end up with a 180 degree system)
But it works perfect.
Nice!

title: Updated Accessory band for the Ruger® 10/22

description.text:
This is an accessory band for my Ruger® Collector Series 10/22. Updated- 02 Nov 15
Apologies, a legacy file was accidentally uploaded previously.
These files should provide a nice tight fit.
Please let me know if there any issues. I have modeled it around the picatinny rail style.
I couldn't justify spending $30 for a plastic accessory band so I could mount my bipod.
So, I just made my own.
There are two top versions available, one with rails and one without.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

as dense as possible

Notes: My bipod has a strong spring which requires a firm support structure. I recommend you make yours as strong a print as possible.

To properly locate the band, remove the front strap mount from the rifle. There is a peg in the lower half of the band that will fit in the hole that is left.
Each part has a small bump which identifies the front face of the band. This necessary due to the taper in the front of the rifle.
Parts hold nicely with four 1 1/2" #6-32 pan head screws and nuts.
This is my first post so hopefully there are not too many issues with the file. :)
Hope you enjoy it.

author: TLC3DP

description.text: I could not find any rounded cylinder in the thingiverse, so I decided to make my own. This version can be used both as a library or customizer thing. Note: After submission, I noticed that there are other rounded cylinders in the thingiverse, like (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58478). However, my design is different than others I found. To use the design in a customizer, just click the "Open in Customizer" link. There are a few parameters that you can fill: Since this thing is a cylinder, we have a radius and height for the main cylinder. For the rounding on the edges, there is a "rounding" parameter, which is the rounding in millimeters on the edges. There is another option, "roundTopOnly" which rounds only the top edge. That is because I frequently needed to round only the top edge. Finally, there is "fn" parameter, which is the number of fragments on an edge. If you want to use the design as a library, you just need to download the .scad file and add "" in your openscad file. Our library supports global $fn, $fa, and $fs variables. Edit: I noticed a few flaws for boundary cases. I fixed those problems. i. There are now more controls on the rounding parameter: It cannot exceed the Radius of cylinder, it cannot exceed the height of the cylinder, and it cannot exceed half-height of the cylinder if both top and bottom are rounded. ii. There appears incorrect (invisible) faces which may cause problems in some renderers. This faulty face is also corrected.

title: 8-LED Neopixel Stripe holder (OpenScad), 2 mount versions, fully parametric

description.text:
Holding frame for Neopixel 8-LED Stripe with 2 different mounting systems to choose (on-top or below plate mount).
I use this in different version on my quadcopters with a standard Neopixel stripe (e.g. available from Adafruit). Neopixel PCB dimensions are defined parametric in the Openscad source code, so it's easy to adapt it to different types...
Space for a 3-wire cable is provided, the cable is to soldered at the given solder joints on the back of the Neopixel stripe.
The mounting type can be switched and adapted in OpenScad source. As provided it fits to my Diatone FPV 250 Quad with 28mm fixing hole distance.

description.text: Just a simple led holder for the naza.

The included print files are 200mm (~8 inches) sections of reed for a rigid heddle to be used on a rigid heddle loom.  It is intended to be mounted in a suitable frame with a 1/8" wide slot routed 3/8" deep.  It is designed so that multiple sections can be installed for wider width heddles.
Included are 5dent, 7.5dent, and 10dent reeds ready to print.
I've also included a parameterized OpenSCAD file.  Any custom dent and section length can be created by changing a few variables.  See the SCAD file for instructions.
The heddle in the photo uses four 100mm sections of 7.5Dent reeds.  That gives it a weaving width of about 16 inches. The sections are printed in natural color ABS with 50% infill.

comments.author: tinaw

comments.text: Thanks!  Yes, i printed that (heddleclamp).  I just added that file to the Thing Files.  However, it was designed around the frame I built.  If you think you might want to use it, just print it, then take measurements inside the rectangular portion for the dimensions you will need.  (I believe I ripped it out of 3/4" dimensional stock - you should check that.)  When routing the slot, make your slot a bit deeper than the tongue.  (Notice that the tongue/slot is closer to the face of the reed than the rear - this was to help keep the shuttle from catching the clamp.) The center portion of the clamp allows it to stretch a bit and then hold the frame pieces under pressure.

Notes: I didn't want to split the SCAD files, so the bottom piece is currently commented out in the design. Uncomment lines 25-31 and comment lines 34-42 if you want the bottom piece. You can adapt this for different sizes of screw by changing the value of screw_diam_tap and screw_diam_free in the design.
The size of the opening for the belt and the clasp for the strap are controlled by constants tongue_width, belt_part_width, and strap_width.

Assembly Instructions
  • Drill the holes on the bottom piece (the piece without the cutout in the middle) to fit the screws you are using (I used #4-40 machine screws).
    1a)Test fit the screws if needed.
  • Place the bottom piece behind the strap on the camera pouch.
  • Place the top piece on top of the strap on the camera pouch.
  • Screw the top and bottom pieces together.
  • If you were lazy like me and didn't trim the screws, you can put some tape or similar to prevent the screws from scraping against the back of the camera pouch.

author: frontier204

description.text: Inspired by Jason Casteel's TARDIS Prime artwork: http://jasoncasteel.deviantart.com/art/TARDIS-Prime-T-Shirt-260357984 I saw the shirt, and had to work out how to make it actually physically work. I did end up having to completely design the transformation sequence from scratch. This print can be assembled without glue or any screws or other non-printed hardware, although you may want to glue some of the parts together anyway if you intend to actually play with it. The only challenging part about this print is the large number of parts (over 70 individual parts needed) and the size of some of the parts (although you should be able to handle everything with a 100mm cube print space). It's a big toy once printed. Tardis mode is about 6 3/4" tall and 3 3/4" wide. Robot mode stands 13" tall - it's folded up pretty tightly when it's a Tardis, unpacks into a much larger toy in robot mode. Honestly I'm not completely happy with the way this turned out. It's large, took a lot of plastic to develop, and the robot mode is incapable of standing on its own. It's too large and top-heavy for the friction in the joints to keep it standing, even though the feet are huge. I may attempt to redesign the entire toy at a smaller scale, to be easier to print and more functional as a display figure. This was printed in PLA on my scratch-built Delta style printer. The original files were drawn by hand in AutoCAD. I have uploaded a zip file containing all the AutoCAD source files. My blog, with information on this and other things I've made, is at http://drewsrobots.blogspot.com/

Head and neck assembly: Print the following parts: 1 headcore (grey or silver)
1 headshell (blue)
1 headantenna_left (blue)
1 headantenna_right (blue)
1 collar (grey, but color of this part doesn't matter much)
1 neck_link (black) Trim the head core and shell if needed until they fit snugly together with the holes in the sides lined up. Press the right and left antenna pieces into the holes to lock the core into the shell. Optionally, use a black Sharpie marker to fill in the eyes on the faceplate. Push the neck_link part through the hole in the collar as shown in the picture. Note that it can go in two different ways, but only one is correct, and you can't rotate it after pushing it in. Press the ball on the end of the neck link into the cup at the base of the head. Legs: For each leg, print the following parts: 1 heel (left or right) (blue)
1 foot (left or right) (blue)
1 ankle (left or right) (white)
1 legblock (left or right) (blue)
1 upperleg (no left or right, both sides use the same) (white)
2 pin_foot (color doesn't matter, I use grey)
2 pin_short (color doesn't matter, I use grey)
1 elbow_link (color doesn't matter, I use grey) Press the pin on the heel part into the hole on the foot as shown in the photo. The heel should be able to freely swing through about 135 degrees. Line up one of the holes on the ankle piece with the other hole on the foot as shown and then press one of the foot pins through to lock it in place. Make sure you get the hole on the ankle, the pin is hard to get out once you press it in. When assembled properly the hook on the heel should lock with the hook on the ankle when in robot mode. The main leg block attaches to the ankle piece as shown in the picture. Line up the thru hole on the ankle piece with the two holes on the bottom end of the leg block, and press a single foot pin through to hold them together. The white upper leg segments are the same on the right and left legs, and attach to the lower leg assembly with one of the short pins. Each upper leg has a flat on one end. When the leg is assembled this flat should be upwards and facing forwards as shown in the picture. The rounded end of the leg with no notch attaches to the lower leg assembly. Make sure you get this right as the connecting pins are hard to get out once you're pressed them in. Put the elbow link into the slot in the top of the upper leg segment, line up the holes, and use the remaining short pin to lock them together. Arms: For each arm, print the following parts: 1 fist (left or right) (grey)
1 pin_short (color doesn't matter, I used grey)
1 arminsert (grey)
1 forearm (left or right) (blue)
1 elbow_link (color doesn't matter, I use grey)
1 shoulderblock (left or right) (blue)
1 shoulderlink (left or right) (black) Press the fist onto the pin sticking of of the arm insert. The fist should be able to rotate freely once attached. The arm insert block needs to go into the opening on the forearm. The raised nub on the side of the insert lines up and slots into the slot on the side of the forearm. Press the raised part down carefully as you push the insert into the forearm as shown in the photo. Once it snaps into place it should slide freely, allowing you to extend or retract the fists. Press the round part of the elbow link into the back of the arm, lining up the hole, and press a short pin through to lock it in place. Press the pin on the elbow link into the shoulder block. The round knob on the shoulder link should press into the socket shoulder block as shown. It should be able to wiggle back and forth with a little effort once inserted. The windows bars on the shoulder block have a narrow slot behind them into which you can insert a piece of white construction paper to make it actually look like a window if you wish. You can also optionally stick a police box decal onto the flat bar part of the shoulder link here as shown. Lower torso: Print the following parts: 1 hip_left (blue)
1 hip_right (blue)
1 abdomen (white)
2 pin_hip (color doesn't matter, I used grey)
1 elbow_link (color doesn't matter, I used grey)
1 pin_short (color doesn't matter, I used grey) Press the pin_hip parts into the two round holes on the abdomen part. Press the left and right hip parts onto these pins as shown in the picture. Put the round end of the elbow link into the slot on the abdomen part. Line up the holes, and push a short pin through to lock it in place. Take the leg assemblies you made earlier and press the connecting pin on the elbow link part on each into the remaining hole on the left and right hips. Upper torso: Print the following parts: 1 backflap (blue)
1 bowtie (red)
1 chest_link (black)
1 lampcap (blue)
1 lampshell (white)
2 pin_shoulder (color doesn't matter, I used grey)
1 torsobodybottom (blue)
1 torsobodymid (blue)
1 torsobodytop (blue)
1 torsotopslider_left (blue)
1 torsotopslider_right (blue)
1 windowflap_left (blue)
1 windowflap_right (blue) The torso bottom part and the two window flap parts also have slots behinds the window bars where you can insert white construction paper slips to give the appearance of windows. Press the two long grey shoulder pins into the holes in the bottom torso part. You can glue these in if you want, but it's not required. Slide the two window flaps onto the shoulder pins as shown in the picture. If you glued the pins in, be sure you don't get any glue on the window flaps as these parts need to swing freely. Press the torso mid plate over the shoulder pins aligned with the lower torso block as shown. Press the chest_link part into the front two holes on the torso mid plate as shown. If you want you can apply a 'police box' decal over the front of the chest link. This part can also be glued in place if you want to make the toy more robust. Put the holes on the shoulder links attached to the arm assemblies you made earlier over the ends of the shoulder pins. They should rotate freely through about a 120 degree range of travel. Take the torso upper piece and press the left and right torso top slider blocks onto the tabs on top as shown. They should snap in securely, yet let the torso sliders slide to the side to open the hole int the top center of the torso, or together to close it. Turn the torso upper piece over. Fit the bowtie into the small slot on the front of the torso piece as shown. Put the two conical nubs on the sides of the collar piece of the head assembly from before into the two indentations on the bottom of the top plate. Line up the four holes on the torso upper piece with the four pins sticking up from the torso lower assembly and press them together. You can optionally use glue, but make sure not to stick the shoulder links or the head assembly in place if you do. Press the backflap piece onto the tab on the collar of the head assembly. The narrow part of the back flap should be behind the head. Take the lamp cap and put the snap on it though the lamp shell and into the hole on the top of the backflap. Optionally, use glue to make the lamp more robust if the toy needs to be able to be played with. Press the linking pin coming out of the abdomen block into the center hole on the torso upper piece. Your toy is now assembled. The file "decals.odg" contains the images for the labels scaled to the model. This is an OpenOffice Draw file.

comments.text: I'd have had an easier time if I'd allowed myself to use screws and pins, but I did this as a design challenge to myself and some of the rules I set were that it be all printed, no glue or screws, and as little support material or post-printing cleanup as possible.  I tried to work with the natural contours and breaks already present in the Tardis, which is why I did things like using the police box signs as slots for the arm links to rotate through.  I'm not happy with how the hips and legs came out, they're too weak.  Your design looks sturdier in that area.

I've been getting similar responses, which is a great feeling. My plan is to (first wait for my 3d printer to turn up next month) then make my tardis transformer & if it works alright, put it up on here.

remixed_from.author: Tech2C
remixed_from.title: Compact Bowden Extruder, 1.75mm Filament for MK7 Drive Gear

description.text:
Just print the parts. Use 2pcs M3x10 screws to attach to the motor (left side). Use M3x16 screw for the idler-to-extruder body. The bearing is standard 608 skate bearing. Attach it with M4x10 (Notice that it's M4, not as the original M5!). If you have M4x12 which is more common in my case - use the spacer. For the Idler tension - you can use a M3 screw bigger than 12mm in length! It's a good idea to put a spring there as you have a notch with which you'll be able to change the filament easily!
Use a push-fitting for 6mm OD PTFE tube (4mm ID). I have a Chinese E3D version all-metal extruder and the PTFE tube came with it. Notice that the screws for holding the Bowden compact extruder to the frame are M4! In the original part - it's M3. When you print with 3mm fila, it's a good idea to hold it steady to the frame. :)
Enjoy! Update #2:
Finally I was able to make everything fit with the 1/8'' brass push-fitting for 6 OD PTFE tube. Everything looks nice - but there is important note that in 1/8'' version - you'll need a 24T gear drive wheel. Like this one: http://www.ebay.com/itm/26T-Tooth-5mm-Bore-Brass-Filament-Drive-Gear-For-DIY-3D-Printer-Extruder-/141353563206?hash=item20e9543446:g:sjoAAOSwEK9TzNeZ
I haven't test it with a hot-end yet... I mount a motor with less torque - if it's working with it, it will work with every motor that has more torque. :) Still waiting for the hot-end to arrive (I hope it will be this week).

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: I printed it with 0.2mm layer height and 50% infill.

comments.text:
Hi, Vvdd. Thanks for the feedback. Every design I'm publishing is tested by me, on my printer. However, I have tested this extruder with a different printer (the one we have in our office - pretty rough tolerances) and I'll print it with my printer to see what's going on. For the print I've made, no files were required for the M3 nut-trap. I'm usually making the mounting holes as per DIN standard (notice that the printers are in 0.2-0.3mm tolerances. For example with my printer: 3.5mm hole will be closer to 3.2mm) because I found that it's better to pre-drill them with the proper drill bits after the print. This saves me a lot of headaches during the assembly.
I've made the design 5 or 6 months ago... Still waiting for the first tests. That's the reason why it's still "Work in progress" and the reason why there is no real picture of a print here. The 3D printer for that extruder is almost ready, though...
comments.author: vvdd

comments.text: the bearing shaft is .2 to big  the designed shaft has to be filled a bit to accept a 608 bearing
comments.author: vvdd

comments.text: Hi there, nice design!
comments.author: Tech2C

comments.text:
Hi, Tech2C!
My motor is NEMA17 - 42BYGHW811 - 4800g-cm /// 2.6A /// 1.8 deg/step.
The first test was to push the filament. It was pushing it with no effort. The motor and the stepper driver was cold due to process. I just make it pass thru the extruder. I've made some test with the bearing close or far from the MK7 drive gear and I think I found the place that it's most efficient. I tried to measure the pushing force and it's between 200 and 700 gr (pretty rough but...electronic scale for the win!). Only the spring must be stiff. I'm using a spring from IKEA clothes pins (they are pretty stiff).
Notice that I still didn't test it with a hotend. I am building a Delta printer (more than 200 cm tall - 500x500x1000 building volume) for a friend and I plan to use this extruder for it. When his hotend come, I'll test everything with it.
On my standart Prusa i3 I already put your extruder! Nice project and I'm really happy with the results. I upgraded my printer with 1.75mm filament.
Best regards and keep up the good work!
Bobby

Welcome to a new development step of my project: ETC "the electric toothbrush clamp" : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:479982 To describe it in short:
The ETC is an holder for the electric toothbrush, to get clamped on an (IKEA) bathroom glass-shelf which is 8mm thick. If you like, you can read the full story here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251150 I thought the second version was already the last edition, but then the printable rubber arrived in my workshop.
I had ordered the fabulous Filaflex and saw there are so many new applications for it!
Sure it's not so easy to print like common materials. Also I had to make some modifications on my bulldog extruder. Finally it was worth to do it. But this is another story. Feel free to drop me a line for sharing experiences about it. Anyway, why not improving an existing project which was missing a flexible material. The previous ETC where held by o-ring segments on the glass shelf. They stood more or less stable and where not easy to remove and replace after cleaning for example.
At least the dragons got supplied with teeth made out of Filaflex. Sure Ninja flex will do the job too.
The tooth shape holds he rubber part in position and looks cool as a side effect. The flat part holds perfect on the glass with the help of the tension of the dragons raw.
Also I’ve made some modifications on the shape of the dragon. Finally I've printed those fellows with HD-Glass from Formfutura which is beside it's transparency also kind of ductile and keeps the needed tension.
Feel free to take a look at the freeCad file for your own modifications and don't hesitate for asking me questions.

author: decado

description.text:
INTRO
It seems to be the month of construction sets on Thingiverse, so here is another entry in the category. Contraptor is a DIY open source construction set for building Cartesian robots. It is basically 1" aluminum Erector set with linear motion extensions. While it's in development and sometimes things don't work as they should, functional robots have been assembled from it: http://contraptor.org/contraptions The set is designed to be made with the simple tools of a basic workshop. A lot of materials for Contraptor like aluminum angle, threaded rods and fasteners can be found in a hardware store. In the spirit of modularity, it uses Makerbot/Reprap electronics and Arduino/Sanguino controller. In addition to DIY plans, we're working on Shopbot-able kits that can be manufactured in small quantities by anyone willing, from open source drawings. Contraptor components and assemblies are modeled in Sketchup and are hosted on Google 3D Warehouse, mostly for ease of accessing from within Sketchup. Thingiverse is the best place to host DXF/SVG sources and part lists for components, so there will be more Contraptor things coming (hopefully including printed ones from the community :). Apologies for the long read, on to the thing:
/INTRO Perforated angle comes in lengths from 1" to 24" and can be used as a structural component, as well as a linear motion rail for sliding elements. Attached DXF file and part list are for 1-ft long perforated angle. Sketchup source:
http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/search?q=contraptor+angle

Aluminum angle stock is center punched with Starrett 819 automatic center punch using pegboard as a guide. Guide holes for attaching angle to pegboard are made with the help of the template (SVG file), paper and scotch. Once center punched, the holes can be drilled on demand. Countersink bit deburrs the holes nicely. Detailed howto and more ways to make perforated angle:
http://www.contraptor.org/make-perforated-angle

description.text:
WARNING: ONLY USE THIS IF YOUR TELESCOPE HAS A FULL-APERTURE SOLAR FILTER OR YOU COULD BLIND YOURSELF!!!! Second Update:
Waiting for the Mercury transit, this thing is great!! as soon as i ger the first pics i will upload it here. First Update: I Finally have some good conditions in my city to test the finder. I upload some images of the thing.
And...
Works nice!!!, The first time you use it, you have to draw a little point or any other mark in the position of the projected point in the finder base, where the sun is in the center of the ocular. This is a remix using thinkercad, the editable source is at this link: https://tinkercad.com/things/2uXa6XaYh42 It is mostly based on the excellent work of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:972686 and using the base of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608140 Thank you for your lovely designs. I recreated them in thinkercad, I use a paraboloid instead of a sphere. Mostly because it is easier to print and do not need any support material. But if you still like the original spherical design it is also included.

title: desk/fridge/metal thing addon rack - magnet edition

description.text:
I have a glass desk with a metal frame. I like a clean desk with no stuff in my way when i am tinkering or working. A few weeks ago i salvaged some nice magnets out of old HDDs. I put one and one together and designed this thing. Glue a magnet in the rack and then put it on every metal surface you like. I think this should also work for fridges and white boards.
With the magnets from a old HDD it is very solid. I think i could also make a bottle holder or something... lets see. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/j37GKr3HzRV

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes: i used fancy alien green PLA :-) I had a little warping :-( but the next ones should do well when my blue tape arrives...

Build
  • Get old HDD out of trash.
  • get magnets out of HDD (or buy)
  • scale rack as you wish in your slicing machine :-)
  • print!
  • glue magnet inside the space for magnet
  • wait till glue is rock solid
  • put it anywhere you like and smile when you put little things in it.

I wanted to make my printer more automated so I created a ram to attach to the x carriage in order to hit prints off. My first thought was to ram in towards the front of the printer but, this requires either the printer to be supported with enough of a gap for prints to fall in a bin or a piece of paper attached to the bed to prevent the part from getting stuck(like on this post I found http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,216570 ). My second thought was to ram it off side of the machine. I added gcode to the gcode that runs when the print is finished a print is finished. credit for the side of the x carriage I modified to clough42. ;called at end of print
G28 ; home all axis
G4 P600000 ; wait ten minutes G1 X300 F6000 ; move x carriage back
G1 Y140 F6000 ; alight the middle of the bed with ram
G1 X0 F6000 ; ram the print with the x axis
;start next print

comments.author: RigoArevalo

comments.text:
Hello,
An FSR is a "Force Sensing Resistor". when you apply pressure to it, the resistance changes. So in this case the pressure of the 3D printer hot end against the printers bed will trigger a signal to indicated that the tip is at 0mm. There are many ways to modify a printer to find Z=0 .... this is just one way. You can find more info here:
https://github.com/JohnSL/FSR_Endstop
comments.author: RigoArevalo

comments.text:
I use this kit - it's got a controller that handles the FSRs for you - you just hook it up like a normal endstop.
http://www.tridprinting.com/Electronics/#3D-Printer-FSR-Controller-Kit

comments.text: I did not have good luck with this vendor. Another friend also bought the same delta. He had better luck at the start. But now he gave it to me to fix. I've changed out all the electronics in mine. I had a shorted RAMPS board which fried many components.
comments.author: Hellblazer204

comments.text:
Walt - Do you have a link for the heater? I'm intrigued. ;-) Mine takes about 5 minutes to get to 95c - mine came with the Aluminum 220mm heated bed, and I've added a 220mm glass plate clipped to the top.
PS: I know the feeling - I've got a ton of $$$ into mine too - I paid $499 for it a year and a half ago. It printed "OK" when I got it, but if I tried to go much faster than 70mm/s, the extruder would just chew the filament. The first thing I upgraded was to print a 'wade's geared extruder', which helped a ton, but still wasn't 'great'. I then bought a planetary geared extruder from eBay - $95!!! But never had any extruder issues after that...
I've probably put at least another $500 into it to get it where it is now, which is very, very good. Check out my profile for the details... http://www.thingiverse.com/jartz/about

While browsing the other day I noticed that there were some pieces for Chinese chess. I've always wanted to own a shogi set, so I spent a couple hours remembering how to do trig, and put a set together from measurements from a Japanese manufacturers' union. Having some trouble with the symbols, though, hence the WIP status. The piece itself prints beautifully, but the piece markings are very low quality. This may turn out better with a smaller extruder nozzle- I'm using .5mm.
Print 1 of each king, 4 gold, 4 silver, 4 knights, 4 lances, 2 bishops, 2 rooks, and 18 pawns.

comments.text: Hi. I made the chinese chess pieces and I'd happily help you wiht this project. Can you upload a "blank" piece with no symbol on it and I'll see what I can do.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text:
Hey, this is exactly what I was trying to make. This is fantastic.
Only, you are right. The symbols on the front sides are fine, but on the rear sides, the promoted sides, they are not.
I am just a beginner at 3D modelling, so I have no clue how to adjust this in your files. Especially this, what shall I say... "grinding away" part of a flat surface. That is something I wouldn't know how to do.
I am Dutch, so my knowledge of of Chinese and Japanese calligraphy is kind of limited. But I do know this: The promoted sides of pieces are in cursive writing. That means, they are a shortened version of the original, complicated symbol. That also counts for the rook and the bishop. This cursive writing is usually in red. You seem to have found the non cursive symbols for the Rook and Bishop.
My idea was to design a set of pieces in which the original writings were present, but would be abundant by using colours for the different pieces. I hate the pieces that indicate the moves of a certain piece, that's for beginners. What I designed is more like a transition effort to go from symbols to colours.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Here's what I came up with: https://pinshape.com/items/2472-3d-printed-iconified-shogi
comments.author: ghanssen

comments.text:
Interesting design, but it doesn't meet my design requirements. I wanted to avoid using indications that shows the movements of the pieces. You wouldn't make inscriptions on chess pieces, just to make Japanese understand the game better, would you? It would be kind of an insult of their intelligence.
But you do need a good way discern one piece from another, that doesn't make use of the Kanji symbols. You can use shape and colour. I chose for colour. I want to add an example of that among my things.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: You mean like /thing:20086 or /thing:5414 or /thing:6976 or /thing:19825? You think those are insulting? I think they're brilliant.
comments.author: ghanssen

comments.text: Ah, you got me on the wrong foot there. :-). The Bauhaus stuff is really brilliant (is it really that old?) and that last one (Stack?) is also very elegant.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: Well, now it's my turn to insult.
comments.author: ghanssen

comments.text: Ah, the joys of not having time to work on things. I've got an internationalized version in the works, but I'd also like to get one with the Kanji symbols working. Next up is the 'simplified' 1-kanji pieces- I think those'll print correctly.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I expected to get an e-mail when you replied to me.
comments.author: aref_naa

comments.text: Okay, I'm an idiot. There are 2 kings, one for each side. I have got to learn this game.
comments.author: cymon

title: Bolt-on Lightweight Ducted fan-MakerGear M2 (& silent build recs)

description.text:
This fan shroud for Makergear M2 allows for a boost in cooling at the point of extrusion, resulting in higher quality prints and steeper overhangs without support. Alternatively, it boosts a quieter and lower output fan's performance to near-or-better than the stock cooling fan. Can be bolted on stock printer with a few fasteners (see below).
Edit 10-26-2015: Woops, this might only work for people with 40x40x20mm extruder fans. A version for stock 40x40x10mm extruder fans will be published later
Edit 10-31-2015: Untested mount and shroud for 40x40x10 extruder fans added. If you do test before I do, I would appreciate a comment as to how it worked out. Overhang Test Results: 45 degrees -> 70 degree (stock vs low speed quiet fan + shroud) Features:
  • Boost cooling performance by directing air where it counts
  • Fan output is centered, not offset.
  • 50mm Fan does not run into frame when homing x axis
  • Compatible with aftermarket "thicker" extruder fans, such as the 40mm x 20mm.
  • Clears stock binder clips
  • Lightweight design

(2) 3mm x 25mm

title: E3D v6 Belt Driven Extruder (3mm / 1.75mm) for Prusa i3

description.text: This extruder is designed for E3D v6 3mm Direct Hotend. Lightly modified extruder body and idler were made by request for 1.75mm Universal (Direct) hotend - these parts have not been tested yet. The extruder can be mounted into Prusa i3 Rework -type X-carriage, which is included in the files. The extruder uses 2mm pitch GT2 belt drive to get rid of backlash and degeneration of 3D-printed gears (got the idea from clough42's 389105). I chose 20:80 pulley-ratio, that will give approximately 600 E-steps/mm with Hobb-Goblin's 7mm effective diameter and 1/16 microstepping (A4988 stepper driver). Highly recommended inductive proximity switch is installed approximately 30mm right from the hotend nozzle. 30mm (or 40mm) print cooling fan is mounted without additional duct as it seems to work for ABS printing. Compared to other extruders I have used (Mak-a-face's 257811 and 725082), the space between hobbed bolt and heatsink's filament entry is narrower and completely open. This makes removal of heatsink easier if filament gets stuck and cannot be pulled away. The center of the mass is also designed to be closer to X-carriage. The trade-off is that the bottom of X-carriage comes closer to print bed, so make sure there's no contact with heated bed cables when print bed moves to the front.

I have designed idler to be used without spring load. Just tighten the 35mm long M4 screws to the end and reliable grip to the filament is obtained. Idler's filament guiding arm prevents over tightening. With high-quality ABS I have not had any problems with this mechanism (so far over 260 hours of printing).

The extruder has four small metal parts that should be easy to made with basic tools: hacksaw, tin snips, pliers, metal file and hand drill. Only 3mm and 12mm drill bits are needed. See attached images for reference drawings.
  • Inductive proximity sensor is mounted by aluminium L-bracket. Cut a piece from 20 x 20 x 2mm L-profile.
  • Small metal arm for cable's strain relief. Made from sheet metal.
  • Bottom plate to direct heatsink's cooling blow away from hotend. Made from sheet metal.
  • Idler's 608ZZ axle is cut from 8mm steel bar, 17-18mm length. Alternatively alum. pipe or M8 threaded rod can be used.

description.header: Extruder is designed to work with these parts:
description.text:
• Hotend: E3D v6 3mm Direct or 1.75mm Universal (Direct)
  • Heatsink cooling fan: 30x30mm E3D fan (2 ball bearings)
  • Print cooling fan: 30mm or 40mm
  • Stepper: NEMA17 (34mm long version works fine)
  • Driver pulley: 20 tooth GT2 pulley
  • Driven pulley: 3D-printed 80 tooth GT2 pulley (STL included)
  • Belt: Neoprene Rubber 188-2GT-6 (link to Aliexpress.com)
  • Hobbed bolt: E3D's Hobb-Goblin
  • Z-Probe: LJ12A3-4-Z/BX Inductive proximity switch, NPN, normally open (link to Aliexpress.com). Works without any additional electronics.

2 x 688ZZ 8x16x5mm ball bearing (hobbed bolt) 2 x 8x12x1mm copper sealing washer (hobbed bolt) 1 x 608ZZ 8x22x7mm ball bearing (idler) 1 x 8x18mm steel axle / alum. tube / M8 thread bar for 608ZZ bearing (idler) 4 x 20mm M4 socket/machine screw (mount to X-carriage) 4 x M4 hex nut (mount to X-carriage) 3 x 12mm M3 socket/machine screw (stepper) 3 x M3 washer (stepper) 2 x 35mm M4 socket/machine screw (idler) 2 x M4 washer (idler) 2 x M4 hex nut (idler) 1 x Ø3mm 25mm self-tapping screw for plastic OR M3 socket/machine screw (idler's bracket) 2 x Ø3mm 20mm self-tapping screw for plastic (hotend clamp) 1 x Ø3mm 16mm self-tapping screw for plastic (fan arm) 4 x Ø3mm 8mm self-tapping screw for plastic (small metal parts) 1 x 2.5mm zip-tie (cable's strain relief) The self-tapping screws I used have been salvaged from broken stuff. https://www.boltdepot.com/fastener-information/type-chart.aspx
http://de.screwerk.com/en/products/stp/stp32.html At the bottom of this page can be found the printing parameters I use with this extruder.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.25 mm layer height

Infill:

30% honeycomb

Notes: All parts have necessary built-in supports. Body's "comb"-supports are 0.5mm width. If slicing generates problems with these, try to change default extrusion width to ≤0.5mm. 0.25mm layer height is recommended for a bit stronger parts. It is one design parameter too. 80T GT2 pulley should be printed with smallest 0.25mm nozzle for the best horizontal resolution. Test printed with PrimaABS™ (licenced from ESUN 3D, I suppose), 230°C Hotend, 110°C Bed. For optimal bond to bed during printing I recommend BuildTak™.

Supports should be easily removable. You might find too much clearance in 688ZZ bearing recesses (design clearance is 0.125mm). Apply suitable thin tape to bearing's outer race for snug fit. Separate bracket for idler need's to be glued into the hotend clamp. I prefer plastic glue (e.g. UHU Allplast) as it gives some time to settle the pieces and a very strong bond. 80T secondary pulley's outer flange need's to be glued too. Attached 5mm thick spacer ring can be left free. Hotend clamp with separate idler's bracket on the right place. E3D's Hobb-Goblin assembly With 688ZZ bearings, standard M8 washer (outer diameter 16mm) would come in contact with both races of the bearing. By using small copper sealing washer or suitable steel shim (OD 12mm) between bearing and M8 washer, the required clearance to the outer race is obtained. Add the copper sealing washers between 688ZZ and M8 washers (come with the Hobb-Goblin). Hint for easy belt tensioning.

description.header: Printing and slicing parameters used with this extruder
description.text: I have run couple of torture tests and found parameters that I use as default for now. I print only ABS so fan is most of the time off. Bottle-neck seems to be counter pressure inside hotend - with 100 mm/s XY-speeds, Hobb-Goblin tends to rasp notch into filament and extrusion stops. Values updated 19.1.2015

DEFAULT_MAX_FEEDRATE (100, 100, 5, 25) DEFAULT_MAX_ACCELERATION (2000, 2000, 100, 10000) DEFAULT_ACCELERATION 2000 DEFAULT_RETRACT_ACCELERATION 2000 DEFAULT_XYJERK 15 DEFAULT_ZJERK 0.4 DEFAULT_EJERK 5.0

Nozzle diameter 0.40mm 0.30mm 0.25mm Layer height 0.25mm 0.20mm 0.10mm First layer height 0.25mm 0.20mm 0.15mm SPEED SETTINGS Perimeters 60 mm/s Small perimeters 20 mm/s External perimeters 40 mm/s Infill 80 mm/s Solid infill 60 mm/s Top solid infill 40 mm/s Support material 60 mm/s Bridges 60 mm/s Gap fill 20 mm/s Travel 100 mm/s First layer speed 40% Default extrusion width 0 = auto (when calibrating extrusion E-steps, I use 0.5mm) First layer width 150% FILAMENT COOLING Fan speed 100/100 % Bridges fan speed 100% Disable fan for the first 5 layers Enable fan if layer print time is below 20 sec Slow down if layer print time is below 5 sec Min print speed 20 mm/s PRINTER SETTINGS Retraction length 1 mm Retraction speed 25 mm/s Lift Z on retraction same as layer height Retract on layer change YES I keep small perimeter printing speed reasonable low so that these values work for most of the prints and adjustments are rarely needed. Pulleys below are printed with above settings. Click picture with right mouse button and choose "open image in new tab" to view it in full resolution. YELLOW: 0.25mm nozzle / 0.1mm layer / 1:48 print time --- BLACK: 0.3mm / 0.2mm / 0:52 --- WHITE: 0.4mm / 0.25mm / 0:47 Same as above Thing:763622. Minor imperfections. The level where auto-cooling starts is about half way and clearly seen. ABS, 0.4mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer height, 59 minutes. Thing:476845. No problems. ABS, 0.4mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer height, 48 minutes.

author: LGermano

description.text:
This bottle mount is still fine after at least 20 casual rides of >20 km each. By casual I mean about 25 km/h on roads and less than 20 km/h on flat but still rough bike paths. It is designed to use the bike's built in screws.
I originally designed it around the dimensions of the "Clean Bottle Original Bike Bottle", but I've used it with a Coca Cola 710mm plastic bottle once - when I forgot the other bottle!
As shown by the file names, I went through a few iterations of this thing before I stopped it from snapping if I shoved in a full water bottle or accidentally hit the mount with my feet while cycling. The only maintenance I needed to do on this thing was tighten the screws on a 35 km ride coming out of the winter. The slots in the stem are made so the screws can get quite loose before inadvertently releasing your bottle.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

=20%

Notes: The whole thing is designed to print without supports and everything is rounded with some print aids as well because my printer has a horrible tendency to bend long flat pieces that I decided to design around instead of try to fix. Despite its use, infill isn't needed much because most of the plastic used will be on walls anyway, rather than infill. I printed this with PLA which holds up slightly better than ABS in this kind of stress. If you want something more beefy, you can go into the files and try increasing the ring_thickness for the top and bottom ring files.

Assembly Instructions
  • Remove a pair of 5mm bottle case mounting screws from the bicycle.
    1a. Make sure you don't lose the screws.
  • Place the stem over top of the screw holes, with the lip of the stem facing down (so gravity doesn't make your bottle fall out the back of the bike!)
  • Slot one of the rings on the stem, and line it up with one of the screw holes.
  • Use the 5mm screw to attach the ring and the stem.
  • Repeat steps 3 and 4 with the other ring.
  • Make sure the screws are tight.
  • Test the strength of the mount by (not gently) installing a full water bottle.

Remix of a model called RecursiveTree.scad. I added a bonanza of parameters in order to come a bit closer to the look of a natural (leafless) tree.  Parameters are for the moment still named cryptically, but change them by small amounts and you see their impact.  Also, OpenScad is thinking a very long time on this when creating a STL file from this tree, but eventually it will come through, as you see in the STL file attached.

These are simple decorations for Halloween. Print them out, and hang them up! You could hide sweets (candy) in them, or maybe use a LED tea-light.
The 'split' files are best for filament printing, the bat should be fine without any supports, the ghost works better with supports.
The 'whole' files will be better printed by professional sintering machines, or if you want to remix the design. The versions without the rings could also make good bowls for the table top.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Depends on size!

Infill:

10%

Notes: Supports for the Ghost, none needed for the Bat

I'm working on putting a ntsc camera on my skydiving helmet. 
This camera mount is meant to be something secure enough to stand up to 120 mph wind. 
So far, it's working out. 
See this device in action at a upcoming event. 
I've added the solidworks files for everybody to use in case anybody wants them.
Find us at www.parahutemobile.com

I started with a board camera as seen here.
http://cgi.ebay.com/1-3-SONY-CCD-Color-Camera-Board-PCB-CCTV-IR-LED-/250863226976 Of course, I added a lens mount, and a fisheye lens. There are many sony board cameras that this design ill work with. You'll need a bit of hardware to hold this all together. 10 - 1" 3-56 screws
10 - nuts for 3-56 screws
4 - 1" 4-40 screws
4 - 4-40 nuts
1 - 4" 1/4 machine screw
3 - nuts to match the 1/4 screw Optional :
1 1/4 screw and nut to old the device down.
or
4 or 6 4-40 screws/w nuts. I went with the 4-40 screws to hold the mount down as I do not want the camera to move right or left. The 4-40 screws go into the side of the base to hold the swivel arms down.
All of the 3-56 screws hold the camera down to it's mounting plate, and 3-56 screws hold the cover down around the camera.

Designed to cut down props with 5mm hub on a cordless Dremel tool.  Will fit any rotary tool with a 3/4" attachment holder. ( see photos )   The x3g file has to tool at an angle to avoid issues on dual extruder machines with no supports, 4 shells, and 20% infill.   
You will need hardware to attach the prop, I used 3/16" steel stock cut to about 1.5" with the first 5/8" threaded with #10-24 threads. (lengths aren't very critical) Other hub sizes could be accomplished by using different hardware. You can just use a 3/16" bolt if you don't mind threads on the entire length. a #10-24 hex nut and wing nut round out the setup to hold it on the jig.

This servo box or bracket was designed to be hot glued into Dollar Tree foam board so that servos can be quickly removed and inserted without having to cut away hot glue. author: mod_extrene

description.text: I like to experiment with radio control aircraft. I tend to use Dollar Tree foam when designing them because its so cheap and easy to do. I made a servo box for a single servo but usually put the rudder and elevator servos side-by-side on the tail. I've had bad landings that damaged a servo or sometimes the servo just goes bad. I got really tired of cutting hot glued servo out of that foam. Hot glue this servo box into you Dollar Tree foam aircraft and you can remove and install servos easily, even in the field. I use a #6 wood screw to hold the servo into the box.

author: waran14

title: The Doryphoros at the MIA / Minneapolis Institute of Art

description.text:
(Quoted from the MIA entry for the Doryphoros): The MIA’s Doryphoros, dating from the lst century B.C., is a Roman marble copy of a Greek bronze sculpture that was made between 450 B.C. and 440 B.C. by the sculptor, Polykleitos. It is the finest of the five known copies of the entire body of this famous masterpiece that have survived relatively intact. Representing an athlete (or possibly Achilles), this harmonious, balanced figure with idealized proportions, typifies art from the Classical period of Greece.
This replica of the Doryphoros has been dated to the 1st century B.C. because of the high quality of the work and the almost total lack of drillwork, typical of this particular period. The rendition of the hair and the form of the support (the stump) also assist us in dating this piece because they can be linked stylistically to other known objects from specific Roman periods. http://www.artsconnected.org/resource/5851/the-doryphoros

Working with Agisoft Photoscan I took over 200+ photos in RAW format from every possible angle of the Doryphoros. He is a challenging subject as he's tall, thus preventing me from getting good coverage of the top of his head. I took close up shots of more intricate parts of him, like his feet, his remaining hand and as much of his head and face as I could capture. I chose to use the RAW format with my camera as I wanted to maximize the potential detail capture. The rotunda where he stands is beautiful, but difficult to photograph in as there is a powerful shaft of bright blue, outdoor light streaming into the rotunda onto the front of the statue while his sides and rear are mainly lit by dimmer, more yellow-red lighting. Shooting in RAW gives me a greater latitude to recover blown out highlights or lost details in shadows. It also allows me to even out the color temperature. After spending a long time carefully evening out all the variations I exported the RAW photos as high quality JPEGs and went to work carefully masking each photo. (I've since learned that I could have just as easily skipped the masking step and still had a great model -- commence face-palm). After finishing the long process of masking, I imported all my JPEG photos and the PNG masks into Photoscan and set it to 'High' at each step. After further tweaking and decimation of the resulting model in Meshmixer, I saved it as an STL file to upload and share here.

comments.text: Looks amazing! Any special print instructions?
comments.author: jknight137

comments.text: I have never had a chance to print it as I don't own a printer (yet). I wish I could give you more advice on printing it. I know Meshmixer is a great app to use for printing and it is free too. If you print it, please share a photo. It is always great seeing how a model translates into a solid real world item.

author: WildPanic

description.text: This was originally inspired from fredhag's wire guide that was made for a Solidoodle 3. I tried that guide and found that it just wasn't low enough for my wire bundle. I started a new one from scratch and dropped the overall design down further and added a more rounded slope. After making the wire guide, I found that I still had issues with the wire bundle drooping and rubbing on the x-axis belt when the print head was roughly in the middle of the print surface. By simply manually holding the back end of the wire bundle up I found that the wire bundle had enough clearance to not rub on the belt. So, I made a little piece that'll hold the back of the bundle up and help with drooping wire clearance against the x-axis belt. For me, there seems to still be enough stretch to make it to the far corner with no problem. After making the wire bundle holder, I ran into another problem. While my wire bundle was no longer rubbing the belts, it was coming too close for comfort near the x-axis motor gear. I made a little wall / ramp in an effort to hold an wires out of the motor area. The overall setup is still not working how I would like it to. The wire bundle doesn't seem to work all the time. If I had to do it all over again, I would make Lawsy's chain guide here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104817 I think that's probably the best universal solution to any Solidoodle wire bundle management issues. What worked for others did not work for me, and what works for me might not work for you.
These should print with just default Solidoodle settings in Pronterface or Reptier.  For the wire holder, you might need to add some support in where it clips onto the case.

description.text: Deux petits adaptateurs pour fixer les fan-ducks prévus dans l'extrudeur de pierrelesek, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512338, de façon à ce qu'ils soient un petit peu plus bas, vu que la tête e3d est plus longue que les autres. Les adaptateurs se fixent en utilisant la fixation du 'hotend-fanmount'. L'écrou encastré dans celui ci peut être laissé, il faut une vis plus longue et inverser les fans-ducks du coup. celui prévu à gauche passe à droite et inversement. Pour l'adaptateur 2; J'ai mis une tolérence de 0.2 mm sur l'emprunte de l'écrou. Dans mon cas, ce n'était pas suffisant. J'ai du chauffer l'écrou avec un briquet pour pouvoir l'enfoncer.

Two small adapters to attach the fan ducks provided in the pierrelesek's extruder , http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:512338 , so they are a little bit lower , as the head E3D is longer than the other heads . The adapters are fixed using the fix for the ' hotend - fanmount ' . The nut flushed on this one can be left , you just need a longer screw and reverse fans ducks: the one provided on the left go to the right and vice versa. On adapter 2 ; 0.2 mm tolerance on the borrowing of the nut. In my case, it was not enough. I had to heat the nut with a lighter to power it down.

author: emiliheli

title: DyslexiaBar v1 and v2 - MakerEd Challenge

description.text:
Hi, my name is Brian Thornber. I am a 16 year old 11th grade student, interested in becoming a 3D Printing Engineer. I've made an object, to help me improve my skills, and to help other people with every day problems. Dyslexia is one of the most common disabilities riddling Americans. It can make it hard to read certain words, or just jumble them all together. That's where the DyslexiaBar comes in. It is an extremely simple design, based off of an age old trick. The DyslexiaBar is extremely simple, in the fact that it blocks out the line of text above, and below, making it simpler to focus on a specific line. It has a keychain loop, for ease of access and thump holders, for grip. It takes about 10 minutes to make, and barley uses any plastic. Also, it makes a good book mark! DyslexiaBar v1 has a larger viewing port, and can hold two lines of text.
DyslexiaBar v2 has a smaller viewing port, and can hold one line of text. Make sure to use plenty of adhesive on the bed when you print. I didn't use enough and it slid during printing. (Thats why it looks a little messed up in the picture) MakerEd Challenge:
Students who have dyslexia, or trouble reading would benefit from using this invention, as it would help them focus reading, potentially helping them with their next English project, History Project, or Book Project.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: It takes about 20-30 minutes to print, and will use very little plastic. Quick and simple.

I came up with this design by remembering what my third grade teacher taught me. Whenever I had trouble with reading a certain line of a book, I would put a piece of paper up to the line and block out the other words, so it was easier to focus on it. This runs off of the same principal, and is easy and efficient to make.

title: Mounting Adapter for Hue Tap on Merten System M
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This adapter allows mounting a Philips Hue Tap switch on top of a Merten System M wall switch. The Tap will also cover the existing switch, so you do not have to worry about accidentally cutting power to your Hue lights. However, if you remove your Tap, you can still operate the wall switch if the need arises. The adapter works with both single switches and double switches.

When installing the adapter, you will typically not be able to come into contact with live wires. However, if you have any doubts about this or if you are not 100% sure that your switch is installed correctly, it is always safer to deactivate power at the fuse box. Please note that installing the adapter might be considered electrical work requiring a license in some legislations. Preparing the Hue Tap Mounting Plate The mounting plate that comes with the Hue Tap will be mounted as rotated by 120 degrees. However, it comes with nib functioning as a key to prevent you from attaching the Tap in the wrong orientation. Simply cut the nib with a sharp knife. Installing the Printed Adapter To install the adapter, you will have to remove the rocker (or rockers) by just pulling them off. The unit consists of a black base that snaps into the wall switch (and keeps the frame in place) and the actual rocker(s) attached to the base. Remove the rocker(s) from the base. If you are careful, this will be reversible. Re-Insert the base into the wall switch. You may have to re-adjust the frame. Then, you can simply snap the adapter into the black base. Installing the Hue Tap Mounting Plate You can easily glue the mounting plate onto the adapter using the self-adhesive pads already installed on the plate. Use the screw holes in the adapter for correct orientation. Please note that as the plate will be installed rotated by 120 degrees, so the mark saying "top" will not be on top. While the self-adhesive pads were enough in my setup, you could also use (very short!) screws. Attaching the Hue Tap Finally, simply attach your Hue Tap to the mounting plate. Note that you can still operate the switch through the hole in the middle of the mounting plate if you twist off your Tap.

description.text:
4/27/16 - Updated left gate to be stronger was having issues with raccoons pulling out the gate to easily and breaking the pivot tab. 
10/25/15 - Changed two STL files from inches to mm  top right small and top left small.  
This is my attempt at designing and printing out a submerged pond water surface skimmer. This is experimental, complicated construction, and there are better way to do this I am sure. I just wanted to see if my idea would work. I am sharing my design as a concept. I have a peanut pond with a ledge that I wanted to make a submerged water skimmer to pull leaves or what ever from the surface. The surface tiles are kind of an after thought. I wanted to print it out on my 3D printer (200x200x185), but it was going to be to large. I broke out the design into smaller parts and made it modular. My choice for filament was Black ABS for the box and Grey ABS for the surface tiles. I glued it together with ABS plumbers glue. I originally designed it to have two gates or one big one glued together. After testing I found my pump didn't move enough water. So I made a snap in fixed part where a gate would be. The design is flexible and can be scaled up or down.

Putting skimmer together isn't for the faint of heart Left and right are when viewing from the water inlet side of the skimmer with openings being closest to the top.. The screen and solid inserts float away so I still need to figure out a fix for that and I may just leave them out. I have orientated the parts as I printed them out and the gate parts will need support material. . The floats are glued to the gate or gates depending. The float STL file is a solid that I used 15% infill when printing to make it some what hollow. I also glued two floats to one gate and increased the bottom float to 125% in the Z or height but kept x and y the same. Take a look at the picture of the float gate to see what I mean.

This is a modified version of the Makerbot Replicator extruder that I am planning to install on my Printbox. Uses two standard Printbox3D hotends and coolers. The extruder is redesigned to use MK8 driving gear and a 604Z bearing held in place by a 4x10 mm screw. Also, the design has been minimized and now the whole thing (including the lever) is just the size of a NEMA17 motor. And yeah, it can handle flexible filaments. You can mirror the parts and easily make a double extruder. There is also a part included that attaches to my 50mm extruder thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1034400
Just in case you want only one extruder.
